lcIntro.p: Relationship tables specify how DITA topics in a map relate to one another. Their prime use is for maintaining sets of related links. They can also define associations among DITA topics and non-DITA resources.
Relationship tables are contained in DITA maps.
lcIntro.note: Although the information is maintained in a tabular format and the containers are called "relationship tables" the table itself is never displayed in output.
lcIntro.p:
A relationship table is contained in the <reltable> element. The <reltable> element is always a child of the <map> or <bookmap> element; a map or bookmap can contain multiple <reltable> elements. The location of the <reltable> is different for maps and bookmaps:
In a <map> element, the <reltable> elements can occur anywhere in the map. However, it is usually placed at the end of the <map> (after the <topicref> elements).
In a <bookmap> element, the <reltable> elements must occur at the end of the bookmap.

In maps and bookmaps, the <topicref> elements indicates the order and hierarchical structure of the content. The <topicref> elements are also used in relationship tables, but in that case the position of the <topicref> in the table indicates the topics relationship with other topics.
The rows in a relationship table contain related sets of content, such as all topics that pertain to a specific system component, or all topics that are related to a particular operation.
Each column in the relationship table contain a similar type of information, such as concept, task, and reference.
Tools that create output from your DITA topics can use the relationship table to create links among related topics.
Move relationships from topics into maps; promotes reuse because individual topics no longer link to other topics; related links depend on maps.
Makes maintenance of linked topics much easier.
